question: A.01 [1.0 point] The following graph for U-235 depicts:

answers.answer: a. differential rod worth curve in the core
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Manual Vol. 1, pg. 57

answers.answer: b. distribution of fission product yield
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: DOE Manual Vol. 1, pg. 57

answers.answer: c. radial flux distribution in the core
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Manual Vol. 1, pg. 57

answers.answer: d. neutron energy distribution in the moderator
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: DOE Manual Vol. 1, pg. 57

question: A.02 [1.0 point] You're increasing reactor power on a steady +26 second period. How long will it take to increase power by a factor of 10?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988. ln (P/P0) × period = time, ln(10) × 26 = 2.30 × 26 = 59.9 ≈ 60 seconds = 1 min.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988. ln (P/P0) × period = time, ln(10) × 26 = 2.30 × 26 = 59.9 ≈ 60 seconds = 1 min.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988. ln (P/P0) × period = time, ln(10) × 26 = 2.30 × 26 = 59.9 ≈ 60 seconds = 1 min.
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988. ln (P/P0) × period = time, ln(10) × 26 = 2.30 × 26 = 59.9 ≈ 60 seconds = 1 min.

question: A.03 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is a number of neutrons in the tritium nucleus (1T3 or 1H3)?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Nuclides and Isotopes. N = A – Z; 3-1 = 2
Correct. Reference: Nuclides and Isotopes. N = A – Z; 3-1 = 2
Incorrect. Reference: Nuclides and Isotopes. N = A – Z; 3-1 = 2
Incorrect. Reference: Nuclides and Isotopes. N = A – Z; 3-1 = 2

question: A.04 [1.0 point] The MUTR Reactor is critical at 100 W. A reactor operator makes a mistake by inserting a sample worth of $1.5 into the reactor core. Which ONE of the following best describes the values of Keff and ρ during the power increment?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.2
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.2
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.2
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.2

question: A.05 [1.0 point] If the multiplication factor, k, is increased from 0.800 to 0.950, the amount of reactivity added is between:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21.  ∆ρ = ρ1 – ρ2 where ρ1 = Keff1-1/Keff1 and ρ2 = Keff2-1/Keff2. Substitute ρ1 and ρ2 with Keff1 and Keff2 into the equation above, the result is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) = 0.95-0.8 /(0.8*0.95)=0.197

Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21.  ∆ρ = ρ1 – ρ2 where ρ1 = Keff1-1/Keff1 and ρ2 = Keff2-1/Keff2. Substitute ρ1 and ρ2 with Keff1 and Keff2 into the equation above, the result is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) = 0.95-0.8 /(0.8*0.95)=0.197

Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21.  ∆ρ = ρ1 – ρ2 where ρ1 = Keff1-1/Keff1 and ρ2 = Keff2-1/Keff2. Substitute ρ1 and ρ2 with Keff1 and Keff2 into the equation above, the result is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) = 0.95-0.8 /(0.8*0.95)=0.197

Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21.  ∆ρ = ρ1 – ρ2 where ρ1 = Keff1-1/Keff1 and ρ2 = Keff2-1/Keff2. Substitute ρ1 and ρ2 with Keff1 and Keff2 into the equation above, the result is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) = 0.95-0.8 /(0.8*0.95)=0.197

question: A.06 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following correctly describes the SIX-FACTOR FORMULA at MUTR? Note: ∞ : infinitive and eff: effective

answers.answer: a. K∞ = Keff * the thermal utilization factor
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3

answers.answer: b. K∞ = Keff * the total non-leakage probability
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3

answers.answer: c. Keff = K∞ * the total non-leakage probability
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3

answers.answer: d. Keff = K∞ * (the resonance escape probability * the reproduction factor)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3

question: A.07 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following describes the term PROMPT DROP?

answers.answer: a. A reactor is subcritical at negative 80-second period
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: b. A reactor has attained criticality on prompt neutrons alone
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: c. The instantaneous change in power level due to inserting a control rod
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: d. The instantaneous change in power level due to withdrawing a control rod
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

question: A.08 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the MAIN reason for operating reactor with thermal neutrons instead of fast neutrons?

answers.answer: a. The atomic weight of thermal neutrons is larger than fast neutrons, so thermal neutrons are easily to slow down and be captured by the fuel
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Figure 2.6, page 2-39

answers.answer: b. The neutron lifetime of thermal neutrons is longer than fast neutrons, so the fuel has enough time to capture thermal neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Figure 2.6, page 2-39

answers.answer: c. Fast neutrons give off higher radiation than thermal neutrons. Reactor needs to reduce radiation limit by using thermal neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Figure 2.6, page 2-39

answers.answer: d. The fission cross section of the fuel is much higher for thermal energy neutrons than fast neutrons
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Figure 2.6, page 2-39

question: A.09 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is the MINIMUM amount of reactivity that makes the MUTR (finite) critical reactor to be a prompt critical reactor? This MINIMUM amount is equal to:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6

question: A.10 [1.0 point] A few minutes following a reactor scram at full power, the reactor period has stabilized and the power level is decreasing at a CONSTANT rate. What is a reactor power level five minutes later from 4 kW?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-t/T = 4 kW * e(300sec/-80sec) = 4 kW * exp(-3.75) = 0.0235 * 4 kW = 0.094 kW = 94 W
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-t/T = 4 kW * e(300sec/-80sec) = 4 kW * exp(-3.75) = 0.0235 * 4 kW = 0.094 kW = 94 W
Correct. Reference: P = P0 e-t/T = 4 kW * e(300sec/-80sec) = 4 kW * exp(-3.75) = 0.0235 * 4 kW = 0.094 kW = 94 W
Incorrect. Reference: P = P0 e-t/T = 4 kW * e(300sec/-80sec) = 4 kW * exp(-3.75) = 0.0235 * 4 kW = 0.094 kW = 94 W

question: A.11 [1.0 point] Reactor A increases power from 10% to 20% with a period of 25 seconds. Reactor B increases power from 80% to 100% with a period of also 25 seconds. Compared to Reactor A, the time required for the power increase of Reactor B is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. The power of reactor A increases by a factor of 2, while the power of reactor B increases by a factor of 1.25. Since the periods are the same (rate of change is the same), power increase B takes a shorter time.

answers.answer: b. exactly the same as A
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The power of reactor A increases by a factor of 2, while the power of reactor B increases by a factor of 1.25. Since the periods are the same (rate of change is the same), power increase B takes a shorter time.

Incorrect. The power of reactor A increases by a factor of 2, while the power of reactor B increases by a factor of 1.25. Since the periods are the same (rate of change is the same), power increase B takes a shorter time.

Correct. The power of reactor A increases by a factor of 2, while the power of reactor B increases by a factor of 1.25. Since the periods are the same (rate of change is the same), power increase B takes a shorter time.

question: A.12 [1.0 point] Two common FISSION PRODUCTS that have especially large neutron capture cross sections and play a significant role in reactor physics. One is Sm-149 and the other is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 8.1
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 8.1
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 8.1
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 8.1

question: A.13 [1.0 point] Which ONE statement below describes a NEGATIVE moderator temperature coefficient?

answers.answer: a. When moderator temperature increases, negative reactivity is added
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 6.4

answers.answer: b. When moderator temperature decreases, negative reactivity is added
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 6.4

answers.answer: c. When moderator temperature increases, positive reactivity is added
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 6.4

answers.answer: d. When moderator temperature increases, no change in reactivity
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1982, Sec 6.4

question: A.14 [1.0 point] During the time following a reactor scram, reactor power decreases on an 80 second period, which corresponds to the half-life of the longest-lived delayed neutron precursors of:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, J. “Introduction to Nuclear Engineering” p. 88. Group 1 is the longest-lived delayed neutron precursor for thermal fission in U-235, with a half-life of 55.72 sec.
Correct. Reference: Lamarsh, J. “Introduction to Nuclear Engineering” p. 88. Group 1 is the longest-lived delayed neutron precursor for thermal fission in U-235, with a half-life of 55.72 sec.
Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, J. “Introduction to Nuclear Engineering” p. 88. Group 1 is the longest-lived delayed neutron precursor for thermal fission in U-235, with a half-life of 55.72 sec.
Incorrect. Reference: Lamarsh, J. “Introduction to Nuclear Engineering” p. 88. Group 1 is the longest-lived delayed neutron precursor for thermal fission in U-235, with a half-life of 55.72 sec.

question: A.15 [1.0 point] You enter the control room and note that all nuclear instrumentation show a steady neutron level, and no rods are in motion. Which ONE of the following conditions CANNOT be true?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988
Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988

answers.answer: d. The neutron source has been removed from the core
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988

question: A.16 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following nuclides will cause a fast neutron to lose its most energy per collision?

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 2.4.5
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 2.4.5
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 2.4.5
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 2.4.5

question: A.17 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following is a correct statement describing prompt and delayed neutrons? Prompt neutrons:

answers.answer: a. are released during U-238 interacts with fast neutrons, while delayed neutrons are released during U-235 interacts with thermal neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988

answers.answer: b. account for less than 1% of the neutron population, while delayed neutrons account for the rest
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988

answers.answer: c. are released during the fission process, while delayed neutrons are released during the decayed process
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988

answers.answer: d. are the dominating factor in determining reactor period, while delayed neutrons have no effect on reactor period
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988

question: A.18 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following conditions will DECREASE the Core Excess of a reactor?

answers.answer: a. Lowering moderator temperature (assume negative temperature coefficient)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. decreasing the reactivity worth in the core will decrease the core excess.

answers.answer: b. Insertion of a positive reactivity worth experiment
answers.feedback: Incorrect. decreasing the reactivity worth in the core will decrease the core excess.

answers.answer: c. Burnout of a burnable poison
answers.feedback: Incorrect. decreasing the reactivity worth in the core will decrease the core excess.
Correct. decreasing the reactivity worth in the core will decrease the core excess.

question: A.19 [1.0 point] The effective target area in cm2 presented by a single nucleus to an incident neutron beam is defined as:

answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 8.2
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 8.2
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 8.2
Incorrect. Reference: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 8.2

question: A.20 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following physical characteristics of the TRIGA fuel is the main contributor for the prompt negative temperature coefficient?

answers.answer: a. As the fuel heats up the resonance absorption peaks broaden and increases the likelihood of neutron absorption in U-238
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: TRIGA Fuel Design

answers.answer: b. As the fuel heats up a rapid increase in moderator temperature occurs through conduction and convection heat transfer mechanisms which adds negative reactivity
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: TRIGA Fuel Design

answers.answer: c. As the fuel heats up fission product poisons (e.g., Xe) increase in concentration within the fuel matrix and add negative reactivity via neutron absorption
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Reference: TRIGA Fuel Design

answers.answer: d. As the fuel heats up the oscillating hydrogen in the ZrH lattice imparts energy to a thermal neutron, thereby increasing its mean free path and probability of escape
answers.feedback: Correct. Reference: TRIGA Fuel Design
